mypathlib¶

icontract does not prevent endless loops at the moment. This is a missing feature in icontract, and needs yet to be discussed, designed and implemented. This is not a blocker, we just haven’t implemented it yet.

sphinx-icontract only recognizes an implication if not A or B. Hence, I always put a “not” even though it might be unnecessary (not (not A) or B will render to not A => B). This is a limitation of sphinx-icontract and will be fixed in the near future.

I noted with ??? whenever I was not sure about something.

Some stats:

  • It took me about 3 hours and 15 minutes to annotate the file.
class mypathlib.PurePath¶

Base class for manipulating paths without I/O.

PurePath represents a filesystem path and offers operations which don’t imply any actual filesystem I/O. Depending on your system, instantiating a PurePath will return either a PurePosixPath or a PureWindowsPath object. You can also instantiate either of these classes directly, regardless of your system.

Construct a PurePath from one or several strings and or existing PurePath objects. The strings and path objects are combined so as to yield a canonicalized path, which is incorporated into the new PurePath object.

static __new__(cls, *args)¶

Construct a PurePath from one or several strings and or existing PurePath objects. The strings and path objects are combined so as to yield a canonicalized path, which is incorporated into the new PurePath object.

Requires:
  • any(Path(arg).is_absolute() for arg in args) ⇒ result == [pth for arg in args for pth in [Path(arg)] if pth.is_absolute()][-1] (When several absolute paths are given, the last is taken as an anchor (mimicking os.path.join()’s behaviour))
  • not args ⇒ str(result) == '.' (When pathsegments is empty, the current directory is assumed)
  • not args ⇒ not result.parts
Ensures:
  • any('..' in arg for arg in args) ⇒ '..' in str(result) (Double dots are not collapsed, since this would change the meaning of a path in the face of symbolic links)
  • '/./' not in str(result) (Spurious dots are collapsed)
  • '//' not in str(result) (Spurious slashes are collapsed)
__truediv__(key)¶

MR: dummy truediv doc so that it displays in sphinx.

Ensures:
  • Path(key).is_absolute() ⇒ result == Path(key)
  • not Path(key).is_absolute() ⇒ result.relative_to(self) == Path(key)
  • not Path(key).is_absolute() ⇒ self in result.parents
__weakref__¶

list of weak references to the object (if defined)

anchor¶

The concatenation of the drive and root, or ‘’.

Get ensures:
  • not self.is_absolute() ⇒ result == '' (No anchor in relative paths.)
  • self.is_absolute() ⇒ result == self.drive + self.root (The concatenation of the drive and root.)
as_posix()¶

Return the string representation of the path with forward (/) slashes.

Returns:

something
Requires:
  • all(len(part) < 256 for part in self.parts) (Contains no path components longer than 255 bytes)
Ensures:
  • not self.parts ⇒ result == '.' (Empty path is ‘.’)
  • '\x00' not in result (Contains no null-byte)
as_uri()¶

Return the path as a ‘file’ URI.

Requires:
  • self.is_absolute()
Ensures:
  • False (??? Can it have an URL fragment? Can it have queries? Is it URL-encoded or needs to be URL-encoded by the caller?)
  • result == "file://" + self.as_posix()
drive¶

The drive prefix (letter or UNC path), if any.

Get ensures:
  • isinstance(self, PosixPath) ⇒ result == "" (Linux paths have no drives.)
  • not self.is_absolute() ⇒ result == "" (Drive of relative paths is empty.)
is_absolute()¶

True if the path is absolute (has both a root and, if applicable, a drive).

Ensures:
  • result ⇒ self.root != "" (Absolute paths have non-empty root)
is_reserved()¶

Return True if the path contains one of the special names reserved by the system, if any.

Ensures:
  • isinstance(self, PurePosixPath) ⇒ not result (With PurePosixPath, False is always returned.)
joinpath(*args)¶

XXXCombine this path with one or several arguments, and return a new path representing either a subpath (if all arguments are relative paths) or a totally different path (if one of the arguments is anchored).

Ensures:
  • False (??? I am not familiar with this function enough.)
match(path_pattern)¶

Return True if this path matches the given pattern.

Requires:
  • self.is_absolute() ⇒ Path(path_pattern).is_absolute() (If pattern is absolute, the path must be absolute.)
  • not self.is_absolute() ⇒ True (If pattern is relative, the path can be either relative or absolute.)
name¶

The final path component, if any.

Get ensures:
  • self != Path(self.anchor) ⇒ result == self.parts[-1]
  • self == Path(self.anchor) ⇒ result == ""
  • os.path.sep not in result
parent¶

The logical parent of the path.

Get ensures:
  • len(self.parts) > 1 ⇒ result.name == self.parts[-2] (This is purely lexical operation.)
  • len(self.parts) == 1 and self.is_absolute() ⇒ result == self (You can not go past an anchor)
  • not self.parts ⇒ result == self (You can not go past an empty path)
parents¶

A sequence of this path’s logical parents.

Get ensures:
  • self.parent != self ⇒ all(p1.parent == p2 for p1, p2 in pairwise(result))
  • self.parent != self ⇒ self.parent == result[-1]
  • self.parent == self ⇒ not result
parts¶

An object providing sequence-like access to the components in the filesystem path.

Get ensures:
  • isinstance(self, PurePosixPath) ⇒ os.path.sep.join(result) == str(self)
  • self.is_absolute() ⇒ result[0] == self.anchor (The anchor is regrouped in a single part)
  • self.is_absolute() ⇒ len(result) >= 1
relative_to(*other)¶

Return the relative path to another path identified by the passed arguments. If the operation is not possible (because this is not a subpath of the other path), raise ValueError.

root¶

The root of the path, if any.

Get ensures:
  • not self.is_absolute() ⇒ result == "" (Root of relative paths is empty.)
stem¶

The final path component, minus its last suffix.

Get ensures:
  • self.name().endswith(".") ⇒ result == self.name()
  • self.name() == result + self.suffix()
suffix¶

The final component’s last suffix, if any.

Get ensures:
  • "." in self.name()[:-1] ⇒ result != ""
  • self.name().endswith(".") ⇒ result == ""
  • self.name() == self.stem() + result
  • self.name().endswith(result)
  • self.name() or result == ""
  • result == "" or result.startswith(".")
suffixes¶

A list of the final component’s suffixes, if any.

Get ensures:
  • result == [] or self.name() == self.stem + result[-1]
  • self.name().endswith(".") ⇒ result == []
  • self.name().endswith(".") or self.suffix() == "".join(result)
  • self.name() or result == []
  • all(not item.endswith(".") for item in result)
  • all(item.startswith(".") for item in result)
with_name(name)¶

Return a new path with the file name changed.

Requires:
  • self.name (The original path must have a name.)
Ensures:
  • result.parent == self.parent
  • result.name() == name
with_suffix(suffix)¶

Return a new path with the file suffix changed. If the path has no suffix, add given suffix. If the given suffix is an empty string, remove the suffix from the path.

Requires:
  • self.name() (The original path must have a name.)
  • suffix and suffix != '.'
  • suffix.startswith(".")
  • not os.path.altsep in suffix
  • not os.path.sep in suffix
Ensures:
  • not suffix ⇒ not result.suffix (If the suffix is an empty string, the original suffix is removed.)
  • not self.suffix ⇒ result.name == self.name + suffix (If the original path doesn’t have a suffix, the new suffix is appended instead.)
  • result.parent == self.parent
class mypathlib.Path¶

PurePath subclass that can make system calls.

Path represents a filesystem path but unlike PurePath, also offers methods to do system calls on path objects. Depending on your system, instantiating a Path will return either a PosixPath or a WindowsPath object. You can also instantiate a PosixPath or WindowsPath directly, but cannot instantiate a WindowsPath on a POSIX system or vice versa.

Construct a PurePath from one or several strings and or existing PurePath objects. The strings and path objects are combined so as to yield a canonicalized path, which is incorporated into the new PurePath object.

absolute()¶

Return an absolute version of this path. This function works even if the path doesn’t point to anything.

No normalization is done, i.e. all ‘.’ and ‘..’ will be kept along. Use resolve() to get the canonical path to a file.

Ensures:
  • result.is_absolute()
  • '..' in self.parts ⇒ '..' in result.parts
  • '.' in self.parts ⇒ '.' in result.parts
  • self.is_absolute() ⇒ self == result
chmod(mode)¶

Change the permissions of the path, like os.chmod().

Ensures:
  • True (??? It would make sense to use old(self.stat()) and compare it against the new mode.)
classmethod cwd()¶

Return a new path pointing to the current working directory (as returned by os.getcwd()).

Ensures:
  • result == os.getcwd()
exists()¶

Whether this path exists.

Ensures:
  • self.is_symlink() ⇒ result == self.resolve().exists() (If the path points to a symlink, exists() returns whether the symlink points to an existing file or directory.)
expanduser()¶

Return a new path with expanded ~ and ~user constructs (as returned by os.path.expanduser)

glob(pattern)¶

Iterate over this subtree and yield all existing files (of any kind, including directories) matching the given pattern.

Requires:
  • not Path(pattern).is_absolute() (Non-relative patterns are unsupported)
  • pattern (Unacceptable pattern)
group()¶

Return the group name of the file gid.

classmethod home()¶

Return a new path pointing to the user’s home directory (as returned by os.path.expanduser(‘~’)).

Ensures:
  • result == os.path.expanduser('~')
is_block_device()¶

Whether this path is a block device.

Ensures:
  • not self.exists() ⇒ not result (False is returned if the path doesn’t exist.)
is_char_device()¶

Whether this path is a character device.

Ensures:
  • not self.exists() ⇒ not result (False is returned if the path doesn’t exist.)
is_dir()¶

Whether this path is a directory.

Ensures:
  • not self.exists() ⇒ not result (False is returned if the path doesn’t exist. ??? How do we check if it’s a broken symlink?)
is_fifo()¶

Whether this path is a FIFO.

Ensures:
  • not self.exists() ⇒ not result (False is returned if the path doesn’t exist.)
is_file()¶

Whether this path is a regular file (also True for symlinks pointing to regular files).

Ensures:
  • not self.exists() ⇒ not result (False is returned if the path doesn’t exist.??? How do we check if it’s a broken symlink?)
is_mount()¶

Check if this path is a POSIX mount point

is_socket()¶

Whether this path is a socket.

Ensures:
  • not self.exists() ⇒ not result (False is returned if the path doesn’t exist.)
is_symlink()¶

Whether this path is a symbolic link.

Ensures:
  • not self.exists() ⇒ not result (False is returned if the path doesn’t exist.)
iterdir()¶

Iterate over the files in this directory. Does not yield any result for the special paths ‘.’ and ‘..’.

lchmod(mode)¶

Like chmod(), except if the path points to a symlink, the symlink’s permissions are changed, rather than its target’s.

Ensures:
  • True (??? It would make sense to use old(self.stat()) and compare it against the new mode. This would need a case distinction for symlink yes/no.)
lstat()¶

Like stat(), except if the path points to a symlink, the symlink’s status information is returned, rather than its target’s.

Ensures:
  • result and not self.is_symlink() ⇒ result.__dict__ == self.stat() (Same as Path.stat())
  • result and self.is_symlink() ⇒ result.__dict__ == self.resolve().stat() (If the path points to a symbolic link, return the symbolic link’s information rather than its target’s.)
mkdir(mode=511, parents=False, exist_ok=False)¶

Create a new directory at this given path.

Requires:
  • not self.parent.exists() ⇒ parents
  • self.exists() ⇒ exist_ok
open(mode='r', buffering=-1, encoding=None, errors=None, newline=None)¶

Open the file pointed by this path and return a file object, as the built-in open() function does.

owner()¶

Return the login name of the file owner.

read_bytes()¶

Open the file in bytes mode, read it, and close the file.

read_text(encoding=None, errors=None)¶

Open the file in text mode, read it, and close the file.

rename(target)¶

Rename this path to the given path.

replace(target)¶

Rename this path to the given path, clobbering the existing destination if it exists.

resolve(strict=False)¶

Make the path absolute, resolving all symlinks on the way and also normalizing it (for example turning slashes into backslashes under Windows).

Requires:
  • not strict ⇒ True (The path is resolved as far as possible and any remainder is appended without checking whether it exists. If an infinite loop is encountered along the resolution path, RuntimeError is raised.)
  • strict ⇒ self.exists()
Ensures:
  • '..' not in result.parts (.. components are eliminated.)
  • result.is_absolute()
rglob(pattern)¶

Recursively yield all existing files (of any kind, including directories) matching the given pattern, anywhere in this subtree.

Requires:
  • not Path(pattern).is_absolute() (Non-relative patterns are unsupported)
  • pattern (Unacceptable pattern)
rmdir()¶

Remove this directory. The directory must be empty.

Requires:
  • not list(self.iterdir()) (??? There must be a way to check this more optimally)
  • self.is_dir()
samefile(other_path)¶

Return whether other_path is the same or not as this file (as returned by os.path.samefile()).

Requires:
  • isinstance(other_path, (str, Path)) (other_path can be either a Path object, or a string)
Ensures:
  • result == os.path.samefile(str(self), str(other_path)) (The semantics are similar to os.path.samefile() and os.path.samestat() ??? I don’t understand what is meant here with semantics similar to os.path.samestat().)
stat()¶

Return the result of the stat() system call on this path, like os.stat() does.

Ensures:
  • result is not None ⇒ self.exists()
  • result is not None ⇒ os.stat(str(self)).__dict__ == result.__dict__ (??? This is probably not what it was meant with ‘like os.stat() does’?)
symlink_to(target, target_is_directory=False)¶

Make this path a symlink pointing to the given path. Note the order of arguments (self, target) is the reverse of os.symlink’s.

Requires:
  • isinstance(self, PureWindowsPath) and target.is_dir() ⇒ target_is_directory == True (Under Windows, target_is_directory must be true (default False) if the link’s target is a directory.)
touch(mode=438, exist_ok=True)¶

Create this file with the given access mode, if it doesn’t exist.

Requires:
  • self.exists ⇒ exist_ok (If the file already exists, the function succeeds if exist_ok is true.)
unlink()¶

Remove this file or link. If the path is a directory, use rmdir() instead.

Requires:
  • self.is_file() (The path points to a directory, use Path.rmdir() instead.)
write_bytes(data)¶

Open the file in bytes mode, write to it, and close the file.

write_text(data, encoding=None, errors=None)¶

Open the file in text mode, write to it, and close the file.

Requires:
  • isinstance(data, str) (data must be str)
